name: 20231111-AL-001
note:
## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2023-11-11T17:56:00Z
## Message ID: 20231111-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux remains elevated, recently crossing the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2023-11-10T09:10Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels observed since 2023-11-07T15:35Z (see notifications 20231107-AL-001, 20231107-AL-002, and 20231109-AL-001) are caused by the consecutive arrivals of CME with ID 2023-11-02T03:36:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20231102-AL-002 and 20231103-AL-001) and CME with ID 2023-11-03T05:48:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20231103-AL-002 and 20231104-AL-001) as well as a coronal hole high speed stream which arrived at L1 on 2023-11-06. The arrival of these CMEs were detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2023-11-05T08:10Z (see notifications 20231105-AL-003 and 20231105-AL-004) and 2023-11-05T11:45Z, respectively. The solar wind speed at L1 reached a maximum of approximately 750 km/s as observed by ACE.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2023-11-07T15:35:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 

The CME arrivals are associated with a geomagnetic storm with ID 2023-11-05T09:00:00-GST-001 (see notifications 20231105-AL-002, 20231105-AL-005, 20231105-AL-007, and 20231105-AL-008). Geomagnetic Kp index reached level 7 (strong) during the synoptic period 2023-11-05T15:00Z-T18:00Z. Simulations indicated that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma was close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2023-11-05T10:34Z (see notifications 20231105-AL-001 and 20231105-AL-006) after the first detected CME arrival and again at 2023-11-05T14:52Z after the second detected CME arrival.

name: 20231110-AL-001
note:
## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME update (ensemble) (STEREO A, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2023-11-10T15:46:25Z
## Message ID: 20231110-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

BETA PRODUCT. ENSEMBLE PRODUCT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT MODE. PLEASE LET US KNOW IF YOU HAVE ANY SUGGESTIONS FOR MODIFICATIONS.  

Ensemble modeling update on CME with ID 2023-11-09T12:23:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20231109-AL-002). Based on analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A. For 32 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- STEREO A between about 2023-11-11T09:08Z and 2023-11-11T21:22Z (average arrival 2023-11-11T15:43Z) for 100% of simulations.

Additionally, the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2023-11-11T11:35Z and 2023-11-12T00:18Z (average arrival 2023-11-11T18:24Z) for 100% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 93% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 4-6 range (below minor to moderate).

Links to the ensemble details of the modeled event:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-11-09_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA052/20231109_122300_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA052_anim_tim-den.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-11-09_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA052/20231109_122300_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA052_arrival_Earth.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-11-09_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA052/20231109_122300_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA052_Earth_stack.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-11-09_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA052/20231109_122300_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA052_arrival_STA.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-11-09_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA052/20231109_122300_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA052_STA_stack.gif

## Notes:
This CME event (2023-11-09T12:23:00-CME-001) is also predicted to have an impact at OSIRIS-APEX, Psyche, Solar Orbiter, and STEREO A. The leading edge of the CME will reach OSIRIS-APEX at 2023-11-11T09:36Z, Psyche at 2023-11-11T22:29Z, Solar Orbiter at 2023-11-11T05:44Z, and STEREO A at 2023-11-11T17:55Z (plus minus 7 hours) based on previous heliospheric modeling (see notification 20231109-AL-002).

Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-11-09_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA052/Detailed_results_20231109_122300_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA052.txt

## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2023-11-09T12:23Z.

Estimated speed: ~782 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 45 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 10/14 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2023-11-09T12:23:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect OSIRIS-APEX, Psyche, Solar Orbiter, and STEREO A. The leading edge of the CME will reach OSIRIS-APEX at 2023-11-11T09:36Z, Psyche at 2023-11-11T22:29Z, Solar Orbiter at 2023-11-11T05:44Z, and STEREO A at 2023-11-11T17:55Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2023-11-11T21:05Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 4-6 (below minor to moderate).

note:
## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for November 01, 2023 - November 07, 2023

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at minor levels during this reporting period with 6 M-class flares and 7 C-type CMEs (see details below). 

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact Missions near Earth:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impact (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2023-11-02T03:36Z   NASA missions near Earth at 2023-11-05T00:28Z, Kp index 3-5 (below minor to minor)
                                       See notifications 20231102-AL-002, 20231103-AL-001
                                       Ensemble results: https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-11-02_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA050/Detailed_results_20231102_033600_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA050.txt
                                       The arrival of this CME was detected at L1 around 2023-11-05T08:10Z.
2023-11-03T05:48Z   NASA missions near Earth at 2023-11-05T08:58Z, Kp index 6-7 (moderate to strong)
                                       See notifications 20231103-AL-002, 20231104-AL-001
                                       Ensemble results: https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-11-03_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA051/Detailed_results_20231103_054800_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA051.txt
                                       The arrival of this CME was detected at L1 around 2023-11-05T11:45Z.


It was also estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact non-Earth locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2023-11-02T03:36Z    OSIRIS-APEX at 2023-11-04T10:15Z, Solar Orbiter at 2023-11-03T13:57Z, Psyche at 2023-11-05T12:00Z (minor impact), 
                     and STEREO A at 2023-11-05T00:00Z (minor impact) (see notifications 20231102-AL-002 and 20231103-AL-001).
2023-11-02T19:48Z    Parker Solar Probe at 2023-11-04T18:46Z.
2023-11-03T05:48Z    OSIRIS-APEX at 2023-11-04T23:29Z, Solar Orbiter at 2023-11-04T10:10Z, STEREO A at 2023-11-05T08:01Z, 
                     and Psyche at 2023-11-05T11:00Z (minor impact) (see notifications 20231103-AL-002 and 20231104-AL-001).
2023-11-05T16:53Z    Parker Solar Probe at 2023-11-07T22:00Z (see notification 20231106-AL-001).


Geomagnetic activity was at strong levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=7 for the reporting period (see notifications 20231105-AL-002, 20231105-AL-005, 20231105-AL-007, and 20231105-AL-008). The highest value of Kp = 7 occurred during the synoptic period of 2023-11-05T15:00Z-18:00Z. This enhanced geomagnetic activity was associated with the back-to-back interplanetary shocks detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2023-11-05T08:10Z (see notifications 20231105-AL-003 and 20231105-AL-004) and at 2023-11-05T11:45Z, which were associated with the arrivals of the C-type CMEs first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2023-11-02T03:36Z (see notifications 20231102-AL-002 and 20231103-AL-001) and at 2023-11-03T05:48Z (see notifications 20231103-AL-002 and 20231104-AL-001), respectively. Simulations indicated that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma was close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2023-11-05T10:34Z (see notifications 20231105-AL-001 and 20231105-AL-006) after the first detected CME arrival and again at 2023-11-05T14:52Z after the second detected CME arrival. The arrival of these C-type CMEs initially observed in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2023-11-02T03:36Z and 2023-11-03T05:48Z were also detected by STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC data around 2023-11-05T03:38Z and 2023-11-05T12:35Z, respectively.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt remained elevated above the threshold of 1000 pfu throughout the first part of the reporting period following a threshold crossing observed during the previous reporting period at 2023-10-29T15:20Z (see notifications 20231029-AL-001, 20231029-AL-002, 20231031-AL-001, 20231102-AL-003, and 20231104-AL-002). These elevated electron fluxes returned to background levels on 2023-11-04. Towards the end of the reporting period, the > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux crossed the 1000 pfu threshold at 2023-11-07T15:35Z (see notifications 20231107-AL-001 and 20231107-AL-002) due to the back-to-back arrivals of the C-type CMEs first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2023-11-02T03:36Z and 2023-11-03T05:48Z (previously described above) and a subsequent coronal hole high speed stream arrival detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE on 2023-11-06.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2023-11-08T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2023-11-14T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between minor and moderate levels during the outlook period. There are currently six numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing solar disk. Active Region 13480 (S08E02) produced three of the 6 M-class flares during the reporting period and may continue to show similar level flaring activity during the outlook period. Active Region 13483 (N10W09) and Active Region 13477 (S15W22) may also exhibit C-level and possible M-class flaring activity during the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. The large coronal hole structure that crossed the Earth-facing central meridian on 2023-11-04 (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO AIA) reached geoeffective longitudes towards the end of the reporting period and is associated with a coronal hole high speed stream arrival detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE on 2023-11-06. Continued influences from this associated coronal hole high speed stream may be observed during the beginning of the outlook period. A smaller coronal hole centered near S30E20 is anticipated to cross the central meridian on or around 2023-11-10 and may become geoeffective towards the end of the outlook period on or around 2023-11-14. Additionally, the > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt currently remains enhanced (see notifications 20231107-AL-001 and 20231107-AL-002) and this elevated electron flux may persist into the beginning of the outlook period.

## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux remains elevated, recently crossing the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2023-11-04T08:25Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels observed since 2023-10-29T15:20Z are caused by a coronal hole high speed stream which arrived at L1 on 2023-10-28, reaching a maximum speed of approximately 625 km/s at DSCOVR (see notifications 20231029-AL-001, 20231029-AL-002, 20231031-AL-001, and 20231102-AL-003). The solar wind speed at L1 is currently around 330 km/s.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2023-10-29T15:20:00-RBE-001.

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

BETA PRODUCT. ENSEMBLE PRODUCT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT MODE. PLEASE LET US KNOW IF YOU HAVE ANY SUGGESTIONS FOR MODIFICATIONS.  

Ensemble modeling update on CME with ID 2023-11-03T05:48:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20231103-AL-002). Based on analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A. For 24 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- STEREO A between about 2023-11-05T05:33Z and 2023-11-05T18:49Z (average arrival 2023-11-05T13:09Z) for 95% of simulations.

Additionally the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2023-11-05T06:35Z and 2023-11-05T22:18Z (average arrival 2023-11-05T14:34Z) for 100% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 72% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 5-7 range (minor to strong).

Links to the ensemble details of the modeled event:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-11-03_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA051/20231103_054800_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA051_anim_tim-den.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-11-03_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA051/20231103_054800_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA051_arrival_Earth.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-11-03_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA051/20231103_054800_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA051_Earth_stack.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-11-03_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA051/20231103_054800_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA051_arrival_STA.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-11-03_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA051/20231103_054800_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA051_STA_stack.gif

## Notes:
This CME event (2023-11-03T05:48:00-CME-001) is also predicted to have an impact at OSIRIS-APEX at 2023-11-04T23:29Z, Psyche at 2023-11-05T11:00Z, and Solar Orbiter at 2023-11-04T10:10Z (plus minus 7 hours) based on previous heliospheric modeling (see notification 20231103-AL-002).

Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-11-03_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA051/Detailed_results_20231103_054800_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA051.txt

## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2023-11-03T05:48Z.

Estimated speed: ~874 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 45 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -3/21 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2023-11-03T05:48:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may affect OSIRIS-APEX, Solar Orbiter, STEREO A, and Psyche (minor impact).  The leading edge of the CME will reach OSIRIS-APEX at 2023-11-04T23:29Z, Solar Orbiter at 2023-11-04T10:10Z, STEREO A at 2023-11-05T08:01Z, and Psyche at 2023-11-03T05:13Z (plus minus 7 hours). 
  
The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2023-11-05T08:58Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 6-7 (moderate to strong).

## Notes:

This simulation also includes the S-type CME with ID 2023-11-02T23:12:00-CME-001 which seems to be overtaken by the faster C-type 2023-11-03T05:48:00-CME-001 CME.

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for October 25, 2023 - October 31, 2023
##
## Message Issue Date: 2023-11-01T21:26:19Z

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low to moderate levels during this reporting period with 1 M-class flare, 1 O-type CME, and 6 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the following CMEs would impact non-Earth locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2023-10-25T13:37Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-10-27T22:02Z (see notification 20231025-AL-003)
2023-10-26T23:14Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-10-28T09:58Z and Solar Orbiter at 2023-10-28T10:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20231027-AL-001)
2023-10-31T21:12Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-11-02T15:48Z and Solar Orbiter at 2023-11-02T20:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20231101-AL-001)

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4.67 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=4.67 occurred during four synoptic periods. The value of Kp=4.67 occurring during the synoptic periods ending on 2023-10-26T12:00Z and 2023-10-27T00:00Z was likely caused by the interplanetary shock detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2023-10-26T03:43Z, which was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE on 2023-10-26. This interplanetary shock arrival may have also been detected by STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC data around 2023-10-26T11:10Z. Further enhancements in geomagnetic activity to Kp=4.67 occurred during the synoptic periods ending on 2023-10-29T03:00Z and 2023-10-29T09:00Z and was likely associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE on 2023-10-28. This coronal hole high speed stream arrival may have also been detected by STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC data on 2023-10-28. The solar wind speed reached values of around 550 km/s and 570 km/s, respectively. 

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2023-10-29T15:20Z (see notifications 20231029-AL-001 and 20231029-AL-002). Subsequently, towards the end of the reporting period, the > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux crossed the 1000 pfu threshold at 2023-10-31T12:50Z (see notification 20231031-AL-001). These elevated energetic electron flux levels are likely associated with the arrival of the coronal hole high speed stream at L1 on 2023-10-28 described above. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2023-11-01T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2023-11-07T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between minor to moderate levels during the outlook period. There are currently six numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing solar disk. The recent M-class flaring in the southeast may be attributable to Active Region 13477 (S15E80) and possibly an additional unnumbered region visible in SDO imagery near the eastern limb around latitude S10 and may continue throughout the outlook period. Additional minor flaring activity may occur throughout the outlook period from recently numbered Active Region 13478 (N12E70).

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. A prominent coronal hole structure centered around S20E40 but with a portion extending meridionally through the equator to about N20 (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO AIA) may become geoeffective starting on or around 2023-11-07. Additional enhancements in geomagnetic activity may be observed during the outlook period in association with the potential arrival of a C-type CME first observed in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2023-10-31T22:12Z. Additionally, the > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt remains enhanced at the start of the outlook period (see notifications 20231029-AL-001, 20231029-AL-002, and 20231031-AL-001) and this elevation is likely to persist into the outlook period.

## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux remains elevated, recently crossing the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2023-10-31T12:50Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels observed since 2023-10-29T15:20Z are caused by a coronal hole high speed stream which arrived at L1 on 2023-10-28, reaching a maximum speed of approximately 625 km/s at DSCOVR (see notifications 20231029-AL-001 and 20231029-AL-002). The solar wind speed at L1 is currently around 490 km/s.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2023-10-29T15:20:00-RBE-001.

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for October 11, 2023 - October 17, 2023
##
## Message Issue Date: 2023-10-18T20:07:05Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2023-10-11T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2023-10-17T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20231018-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity varied between low and minor levels during this reporting period with 1 M-class flare and 7 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the C-type CME first visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery at 2023-10-16T12:09Z may give a glancing blow to NASA missions near Earth at about 2023-10-19T15:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) with a maximum estimated Kp index of 2-4 (below minor) (see notification 20231017-AL-001). An ensemble simulation was performed for this CME with 32 members which estimated the CME to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2023-10-19T09:28Z and 2023-10-19T17:33Z (average arrival 2023-10-19T13:30Z) for 6% of simulations. The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 66% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-4 range (below minor). Full details of the modeled event are available here: https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-10-16_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA048/Detailed_results_20231016_120900_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA048.txt (see notification 20231017-AL-002).

It was also estimated that the following CMEs would impact non-Earth locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Location/Mission Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2023-10-11T23:36Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-10-13T04:52Z and Solar Orbiter at 2023-10-12T17:37Z (see notification 20231012-AL-001)
2023-10-12T07:36Z   Solar Orbiter at 2023-10-13T08:00Z (glancing blow)
2023-10-12T14:12Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-10-14T14:00Z (glancing blow) and Solar Orbiter at 2023-10-13T22:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20231012-AL-002)
2023-10-15T23:12Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-10-17T16:00Z (glancing blow) and Solar Orbiter at 2023-10-17T04:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20231016-AL-001)
2023-10-16T12:09Z   OSIRIS at 2023-10-19T08:15Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2023-10-18T01:10Z, Solar Orbiter at 2023-10-17T08:26Z, and STEREO A at 2023-10-19T15:00Z (glancing blow) (see notifications 20231016-AL-002 and 20231017-AL-001)

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3.67 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

2023-10-16T06:36Z     ~544            C                70/0                 19                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2023-10-18T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2023-10-24T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between minor and moderate levels throughout the outlook period. There are currently three numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13464 (currently located at N04W42) exhibited C-class flaring throughout the reporting period and may continue to exhibit flaring activity before it rotates off the Earth-facing disk around 2023-10-22. Additional flaring activity may occur throughout the outlook period from an unnumbered region currently visible in SDO imagery around N25E60.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and below minor levels during the outlook period. A slight increase in geomagnetic activity may be observed around 2023-10-19 in association with the predicted arrival of a C-type CME first observed in STEREO A COR2 at 2023-10-16T12:09Z (see notifications 20231016-AL-002, 20231017-AL-001, and 20231017-AL-002) as previously summarized above. Additionally, a small coronal hole currently centered around N45W20 (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO) may reach geoeffective longitudes on or around 2023-10-22.

Based on analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A. For 32 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- STEREO A for an average arrival of 2023-10-19T09:41Z for 3% of simulations.

The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 66% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-4 range (below minor).

https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-10-16_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA048/20231016_120900_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA048_arrival_Earth.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-10-16_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA048/20231016_120900_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA048_Earth_stack.gif

## Notes:
This CME event (2023-10-16T12:09:00-CME-001) is also predicted to have an impact at OSIRIS at 2023-10-19T08:15Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2023-10-18T01:10Z, and Solar Orbiter at 2023-10-17T08:26Z (plus minus 7 hours) based on previous heliospheric modeling (see notifications 20231016-AL-002 and 20231017-AL-001).

Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:

## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Parker Solar Probe, Solar Orbiter, STEREO A, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2023-10-16T16:33:11Z
## Message ID: 20231016-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2023-10-16T12:09Z.

Estimated speed: ~720 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 35 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -45/13 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2023-10-16T12:09:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect Parker Solar Probe, Solar Orbiter, and STEREO A (glancing blow). The leading edge of the CME will reach Parker Solar Probe at 2023-10-18T00:09Z and Solar Orbiter at 2023-10-17T08:35Z. The flank of the CME will reach STEREO A at 2023-10-19T16:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the flank of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2023-10-19T16:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 2-4 (below minor).
   
  
Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2023-10-16T12:09:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20231016_170600_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_SolO_timeline.gif


## Notes: 

This CME event (2023-10-16T12:09:00-CME-001) is associated with C7.5 flare with ID 2023-10-16T10:32:00-FLR-001 from Active Region 13467 (N13E47) which peaked at 2023-10-16T10:51Z.

## Summary:

Update on CME with ID 2023-10-10T10:24:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20231010-AL-001).  Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may affect Lucy (glancing blow). The flank of the CME will reach Lucy around 2023-10-17T12:00Z (plus minus 7 hours).

Previous simulations also estimate that the CME may affect Mars, Parker Solar Probe and Solar Orbiter.  The leading edge of the CME may reach Mars at 2023-10-14T10:13Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2023-10-11T06:41Z, and Solar Orbiter at 2023-10-10T22:40Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

CME parameters are (O-type):

Start time of the event: 2023-10-10T10:24Z.

Estimated speed: ~1197 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 50 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -125/9 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2023-10-10T10:24:00-CME-001

## Notes: 
This 5.5 AU simulation was executed two days after the CME event was observed. The real-time configuration of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model at CCMC uses the most recent magnetogram available. Because of the use of a later magnetogram in this 5.5 AU simulation, the 5.5 AU results above may be more approximate than the 2AU simulation results.
